Review: The Aftermath Exhibition

By James Bithell

A varied and unusual exhibition, 'The Aftermath Exhibition' is well-worth the venture to the top of Micklegate. Carys Brain reviews.

Review: The Making of Landscape

An all-star cast boasting some of the world's greatest Landscape artists, The Making of Landscape leaves you feeling unexpectedly cheated. Roisin Astell reviews.

By James Bithell

Drama Barn's first offering this term is an impressive performance, but leaves much to be desired. Lizzie Stephens reviews.

Review: Junior Officers' Reading Club - Patrick Hennesy

By James Bithell

The Junior Officer's Reading Club bridges a long unspoken gap between civilian and soldier, giving a transparent, comic, and brutally honest explanation supporting those either side of the divide. Poppy Bullard reviews.

Portrait of a Lady

Paul Emsley's attempt at photorealism in his recent portrait of the Duchess of Cambridge has Aggie Torrance unconvinced.

By James Bithell

Review: La Boheme

By James Bithell

The Royal Opera House hosts an opera in four acts which transported the audience to the centre of Parisian romance, with a stunning set and acting to match.

Carys meets members of the cast of the Royal York's Christmas pantomime Robin Hood, and finds out why dispensing with the script is just part and parcel of the job.

Review: Greenland

Review: The Nutcracker

The Vienna Festival Ballet were hosted by the Grand Opera House. The dance and movement caught the magic of the Christmas, but the lack of orchestra failed to charm.

Review: Sitting Room Comedy

Dana Alexander was a highlight in a line-up of well-chosen acts, but the long sets left some performers lacking spark.

Review: Bloody Poetry

An astonishingly unique and provocatively philosophical show that will not fail to entertain. Thomas Cox reviews.

Review: Birdsong

An outstanding piece of Drama Barn theatre that perfectly captures the tumultuous dynamics of World War One. Lucie Parker reviews.

Art and Internationalism

By James Bithell

Nasser Azam's work as a banker and artist have taken him all over the world, from Pakistan and Antartica, to 5 miles above the Earth. Laura Hughes is charmed by this most vivacious of characters. (Thumbnail credit Athena, London, July 2012)

Review: Les Miserables
